did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: The R. H. Smith papers contain three letters, one of which has a typed transcription. Several incidents described in the letters relate to the Texas Revolution.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: R. H. Smith Papers worked as a clerk and later a merchant in Bayou Sara, in West Feliciana Parish, Louisiana. Located on the bank of the Mississippi River, it was the largest port city between New Orleans, Louisiana and Memphis, Tennessee. In 1836, Smith saw Generals Sam Houston and Felix Huston in Baton Rouge and the Schooner Independence in New Orleans. By 1839, Smith moved to Vandalia, Illinois, which served as the state capitol through that year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The R. H. Smith papers consist of one folder, beginning in 1836 and ending in 1839. One letter describes Smith's experience in seeing a wounded Sam Houston carried off the Texas navy ship Independence in New Orleans, after the Battle of San Jacinto. Houston had come to New Orleans for surgery on his wounded ankle. Also in the letter is a sketch of the ensign flown by the Independence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The R. H. Smith papers were not organized prior to this finding aid.
Currently, the R. H. Smith papers are organized in one series: I. Personal Correspondence.
